SUBJECT: Vote on Program Submission:
Science and Society
Pairleigh Dickinson U.
A On the basis of the audition tape, I have little choice but to
/ vote for the rejection of this one. The show is slow moving,
< stuffy, and amateurish to an exteme. On top of all that, the
I recording quality is very bad.
/ On this last point, I hate to vote on the basis of recording
quality when I have only heard a single tape-since there is
/ always the possibility that I received a bad dub, or that my
/ playback machine is at fault. I checked this one on three
. machines, however—two Berlants and an Ampex—and it always came
out with a 15 percent noise level, low frequency response, and
several annoying burbles which sounded as if the original master
had had some bad splices in it.
/ Disregarding the recording quality, this was not a good show
upon which to Judge the series. In case you haven't heard it,
the audition submitted was the opening show of a fifteen show
series. We start off by killing 40 seconds establishing the
fact that the series of I5 “Science and Society" programs we are
\ about to hear is part of a larger series called "This is
) Pairleigh Dickinson University," or some such. The moderator
then shoots another minute and 10 seconds with an outline of what
is to be discussed and how during the next four months.
The discussion. Itself, when we finally get into it, is pretty
- contrived and gives evidence of having been scripted and re¬
hearsed down to the last comma—and you know what scripted
^/' discussion sounds like.
Actually, however, I hate to vote for complete rejection without
having heard one of the later shows in the series. The list of
people from industrial firms Involved in the later shows is
^ Impressive and suggests that there might be some truly Interesting
